column13: Without the support and network of QCBS I would not have found my research supervisor, nor would I have been able to delve into statistical analysis due to their R workshops. More so, being a student member of QCBS during my undergrad allowed me the opportunity to be apart of the North American Dialogue on Biocultural Diversity.  Being able to attend such a monumental gathering that was backed by the UN and the Convention on Biological Diversity would not have been possible had QCBS not existed. Through that dialogue I was able to gain tremendous insight into much research that was needed, as well as actions required. It also allowed for my exposure to many strong and powerful indigenous voices. This conference had a strong and lasting impact on me as a scientist, research, and citizen. It has shaped my research,  my goals, and my motivations.  None of this knowledge, nor network would have been accessible or possible without QCBS.
column19: As I take the next step towards my Master's, the impact that QCBS had on my career cannot be emphasized enough. Thanks to QCBS I was able  o develop in depth skills in terms of statistical analysis through the QCBS R workshop. As well their QGIS seminars have opened so many doors for me as I pursue higher education.  But more than just the amazing workshops, annual conference, the concrete and usable knowledge gained, is also the network, the community that this outstanding organization has fostered. Having access to other researchers, to mentors, to knowledgeable experts, all quick to help do to us being apart of such a strong organization, this has had benefits that are hard to put into words. I beg of FQRNT, do not cut funding for this amazing organization, it has helped so many of the Quebec student population, in too many ways to mention. In direct and indirect, it has help push our voices and deepen our research. Please do not remove this opportunity for the students of tomorrow, especially in such a crucial time for the environment.

Ces ateliers ont été extrêmement bénéfiques pour ma progression en tant qu'enseignant/chercheur. 

Le cours intensif sur la biodiversité du Québec, a été un tournant dans mon parcours académique, il m'a ouvert des perspectives inconnues avant cela et m'a fait rencontrer un grand nombre d'étudiants et chercheurs aujourd'hui encore amis ou collaborateurs.

Le colloque annuel du CSBQ permet aux étudiants de présenter leurs travaux dans un cadre académique d'exception.  Le niveau scientifique est excellent, l'exigence est grande tout cela dans un cadre amicale, décomplexé et très accessible. Pour un étudiant en début de carrière en recherche, ce colloque est une très belle manière de se confronter à la présentation scientifique sans l'angoisse des colloques internationaux très compétitifs. 

Le réseau des chercheurs du CSBQ m'a permis de faire des collaborations pendant mon doctorat, de faire des échanges et rencontrer un très grand nombre de chercheurs. Le réseau encourage grandement les interactions et soutiens tout type d'initiative étudiante.

J'ai eu la chance d'être représentant étudiant de l'université de Sherbrooke pendant plus de 4 ans et d'être représentant global pendant un an. Avec l'autre représentant global, devenu ami  nous avons  organisé un workshop sur les méta-analyses. Le soutien du CSBQ tant sur le plan financier Qu'organisationnel a permis l'organisation et le bon déroulement du workshop. Toutes les initiatives étudiantes sont considéré et évalué pour maximiser le retour à l'échelle du réseau, tant pour le développement des carrières étudiantes que sur le plan de la stimulation scientifique. 

Le réseau du CSBQ est un lieu unique de rencontre, discussion et partage. Il permet le financement de manifestation scientifique et académique. Il soutient les étudiants dans leurs développements scientifiques. Le CSBQ offre un soutien financier aux étudiants et plus important encore il offre une exceptionnelle occasion de s'impliquer dans un réseau national. La direction du CSBQ est accessible et communique bien. Le financement du CSBQ donne l'occasion à la province de Québec de construire une institution forte, dynamique et perenne autour des questions de Biodiversité. En ces temps de grands changements écologiques, ce centre est un partenaire incontournable d'une politique d'action. Il est l'interlocuteur de choix pour répondre aux enjeux scientifiques, sociaux et politiques à l'échelle national et plus largement dans le monde francophone.

column13: QCBS is a wonderful, multi-faceted entity. When I moved to Quebec for my master's program, I was thrilled to learn about QCBS, wishing we had a similar organization in Ontario. QCBS provides opportunities to share research, hone academic skills and support new researchers. As a recipient of a QCBS Excellence Award, I was able to participate in an international training opportunity -otherwise I would not have been able to do so. The annual symposium allowed me to share some of my research by participating in the poster session. I was able to share my findings and discuss with peers who were using similar theory with different applications. This was an exciting exchange, as I would never have been able to share my knowledge and contribute to their projects, providing new avenues to explore to support their investigations (I study primate route decision-making, while the other researcher studies human decision-making in video games). I have also found the workshops in R to be very helpful. In addition to the financial support I've received, this practical support has been useful. Being able to discuss with others directly has made the learning curve relating to R much more bearable. I would be saddened for future new graduate students if QCBS doesn't survive the funding limitations. I think it's a worthwhile project and organization. It would be a shame for it to be limited in the support it offers.

column13:
The R workshops provided training that I would otherwise never have gotten through my M.Sc. or Ph.D., both in terms of programming and even in terms of statistics. Without these workshops, I would have had a much harder time completing my M.Sc. and getting to the point where I could do a Ph.D.

I also have not had many opportunities to teach courses, which can be important for future work. The R workshops are a great opportunity to practice teaching, and the annual R symposiums are a great encouragement to create teaching material and present it. I really value this opportunity, as I would otherwise have no teaching experience.

I took the annual QCBS Biodiversity Science course in my first year as a graduate student, and found it to be incredibly valuable as an opportunity to meet PIs involved in the QCBS, as well as other graduate students. I stayed friends with many of these students, and have even collaborated on projects, exchanged ideas, and given trainings with them over the years. It gave me lasting connections with students in other QC universities who I would maybe never have met otherwise, and this has already majorly contributed to my academic career.
column16:
Went to an intensive course at the University of South Bohemia in Czech Republic, and presented my research at several international conferences.

My most beneficial experience was presenting a poster at the International Biogeography Society conference in Tucson, Arizona, near the middle of my M.Sc. As a relatively new student, I was still very unsure of myself and my work, and was in need of a confidence boost. Presenting a poster at this conference, where I was able to speak with many of the researchers I admired and had cited profusely, definitely gave me confidence in my ability to do research and have good ideas and insight. It was a turning point for me.
column19: Lots of friends, experience, and empowerment to contribute to international-level research.
